frontMatter.intro: In some questions, either none of the options or all of them may apply to the user. This pattern addresses how to handle these situations.

when_to_use.value: **All or none scenarios.** When users may need to select either none or all available options in response to a question.

design_principles.value: **Checkboxes: Include 'select all that apply'.** Add instructional text when using checkboxes.
**Avoid dedicated all/none checkboxes.** Users can already select multiple or zero checkbox options.
**Radio buttons: Include all/none options last.** When genuinely mutually exclusive, add 'all of these' or 'none of these' after other options.
**Consider alternatives.** Reframe the question, break into separate questions with conditional logic, or explicitly state that selection is optional.

examples.description: Checkbox group with instructional text allowing multiple or no selections.

examples.title: Radio buttons with none option
examples.description: Radio button list including a "None of these" option at the end.

how_to_build.intro: Choose the appropriate form control based on the selection requirements.

steps.value: For checkboxes, include 'select all that apply' instructional text.
Don't create dedicated 'all of these' checkboxes—users can already select all.
Don't create dedicated 'none of these' checkboxes—users can already select none.
For radio buttons, include 'all of these' or 'none of these' as the last options.
For select boxes, follow radio button rules for all/none options.

accessibility.value: Ensure instructional text like 'select all that apply' is associated with the fieldset.
Screen readers should announce the selection instructions.
All options must be keyboard accessible.

docs.title: A single response
docs.description: Follow this pattern to collect one logical piece of information at a time, allowing users to focus on specific questions.

frontMatter.title: A single response
frontMatter.description: Follow this pattern to collect one logical piece of information at a time, allowing users to focus on specific questions.
frontMatter.intro: Asking for one logical thing at a time allows users to focus on what you are asking from them. While a page may contain multiple form fields, the "one thing" refers to the information being gathered conceptually.

when_to_use.value: **Collecting related responses.** When collecting one or a few related responses from users.
**Reducing complexity.** When dividing long forms into logical sections.
**Focused information gathering.** When situations require clear, focused questions.

design_principles.value: **One thing per page.** This encompasses: one piece of information, one decision, or one question.
**Limit conditional reveals.** When using conditional reveals, limit to one per page.
**Make revealed questions clear.** Conditionally revealed questions should be self-explanatory.
**Create distinct error messages.** Each field should have its own error message.

when_not_to_use.value: **Multiple similar items.** When collecting the same data about multiple items, use the Multiple Responses pattern.
**Unknown quantity.** When gathering an unknown quantity of responses, use the Multiple Responses pattern.

**Validate in real-time.** Validate formatting upon entry to catch mistakes immediately.

when_to_use.value: **Collecting the same data repeatedly.** When gathering the same information across multiple items.
**Unknown quantity of responses.** When the number of items to collect is not predetermined.
**1 to n items.** When forms need repeated similar information across one or more items.

design_principles.value: **Use multi-page approach.** The default approach allows flexible data collection following 'one thing per page'.
**Provide required and optional variants.** Required variant needs at least one item; optional allows skipping entirely.
**Include summary page.** Show all collected items with edit and delete capabilities.
**Use zero-based indexing.** URL structure: /dependents/0/name for first item, /dependents/1/name for second.

when_not_to_use.value: **Single or limited responses.** When collecting single or limited responses, use the Single Response pattern.
**Different questions per item.** When questions differ for each item.

**Required variant:** At least one item must be added before proceeding.
**Optional variant:** Users may skip the section entirely.
**Add item variant:** Displays existing items as list with 'Add a new item' link. Best when data already exists.

Provide edit and delete capabilities on summary page.
Use modal for delete confirmation.

frontMatter.code_usage:
The multiple responses pattern (also known as List & Loop) handles repeated data collection.

**URL Structure:**
```
/<form-root>/<section>/<array-name>/<index>/<question-path>
```

**Examples:**
- First dependent: `/form/dependents/0/name`
- Second dependent: `/form/dependents/1/name`

Use built-in error/validation messages and maintain consistent terminology throughout.

Pre-populate fields during edits.

accessibility.value: Edit links and delete buttons require accessible text so screen reader users understand what is being edited or deleted.

docs.title: Signature
docs.description: Follow this pattern to capture digital signatures when forms require users to certify information.

frontMatter.title: Signature
frontMatter.description: Follow this pattern to capture digital signatures when forms require users to certify information.
frontMatter.intro: Use this pattern when forms require users to certify information through a statement of truth. An e-signature has the same legal weight as a handwritten signature under federal law.

when_to_use.value: **Forms requiring certification.** When users must certify the accuracy of their submission through a statement of truth.
**Legal compliance.** When forms must comply with electronic signature regulations (GPEA, UETA, ESIGN).

design_principles.value: **Do not add a privacy policy checkbox.** The signature pattern replaces the need for a separate privacy acknowledgment.
**Use Statement of truth component.** Implement the dedicated component rather than alternatives.
**Include proper timestamps.** All signatures must include UTC date and time stamps.
**Indicate authentication level.** Watermarks must reflect whether the user was unauthenticated, IAL1, or IAL2.

when_not_to_use.value: **Not all forms need this.** Only use for forms that specifically require certification or statement of truth.

examples.description: Signature section with certification statement and text input for user's name.

examples.title: PDF with signature
examples.description: Generated PDF showing signature field, date signed, and authentication watermark.

how_to_build.intro: The signature pattern captures electronic signatures that comply with federal regulations.

steps.value: Include instructions around signing the certification.
Use a card container for the signature section.
Implement the Statement of truth component.
For PDFs, include: signature field (user's name), date signed (UTC), and authentication watermark.
Watermark format varies by authentication level: unauthenticated, IAL1, or IAL2.

frontMatter.code_usage:
The signature pattern is implemented using the Statement of truth component.

**PDF Requirements:**
- Signature Field: Veteran's name from Statement of truth input
- Date Signed: Current submission date (UTC)
- Watermark: Bottom-right with authentication level and timestamp
- VA DATE STAMP Box: Fill when form includes it (upper right corner)

**Watermark formats by authentication level:**
- Unauthenticated: "Signed electronically at [HH:MM] UTC [YYYY-MM-DD]. Signee not signed in."
- IAL1: "...hasn't verified their identity."
- IAL2: "...signed with an identity-verified account."

content_considerations.value: Use UTC timezone for all date/time stamps.
Timestamps should reflect initial submission date, not PDF generation date.
For signed-in users, use their authenticated name for the signature field.

accessibility.value: Ensure the signature input field has a clear, visible label.
The statement of truth must be readable by screen readers.
Provide clear instructions about what the user is certifying.

**Prefill when possible.** Use existing data from VA systems when available.

frontMatter.intro: The wizard pattern was designed to guide users through complex VA benefit eligibility pathways. It is deprecated due to difficult-to-solve accessibility issues. Use the "Complete a sub-task" pattern instead.

when_to_use.value: **Complex eligibility.** Previously used to help users understand complex eligibility requirements for VA benefits.
**One question at a time.** Presented one question at a time to avoid showing irrelevant content.
**Branching logic.** Used branching logic to direct users to optimal pathways based on their circumstances.

design_principles.value: **Deprecated.** This pattern is deprecated due to accessibility issues.
**Use sub-task pattern.** Replace with the 'Complete a sub-task' pattern.

when_not_to_use.value: **All new implementations.** Do not use this pattern for any new implementations.
**Accessibility concerns.** This pattern has difficult-to-solve accessibility issues that negatively impact screen reader users and keyboard navigation.

how_to_build.intro: This pattern is deprecated. Use the "Complete a sub-task" pattern instead.

steps.value: This pattern is deprecated and should not be used in new implementations.
Replace with the 'Complete a sub-task' pattern.

content_considerations.value: For teams unable to immediately migrate, minimize accessibility issues by asking qualifying questions upfront in forms.

frontMatter.title: Accessibility guidelines for forms
frontMatter.description: Detailed accessibility requirements and implementation guidance for forms on VA.gov.
frontMatter.intro: This template provides detailed accessibility requirements and implementation guidance for forms on VA.gov, ensuring Veterans with disabilities can access and complete essential services. Approximately 1 in 4 Veterans live with service-connected disabilities.

when_to_use.value: **All form implementations.** These guidelines apply to all forms on VA.gov.
**Section 508 compliance.** Forms must comply with Section 508 and Americans with Disabilities Act requirements.
**Universal usability.** Addresses technical accessibility, cognitive accessibility, and universal usability principles.

structure.intro: The guidelines cover focus management, form labeling, validation, cognitive accessibility, and testing requirements.

sections.title: Managing Focus in Form Flows
sections.description: Single-page applications must manually set focus when users move between pages since focus doesn't reset automatically.

sections.title: Where to Move Focus
sections.description: If page has unique heading (H1 or H3), set focus there. Without unique heading, set focus on step indicator header (H2).

sections.title: Form Labeling and Structure
sections.description: Each form step needs unique H3 describing current step. Use consistent fieldset/legend patterns across all steps.

sections.title: Input Validation and Error Handling
sections.description: Validate required fields when users attempt to continue. Move focus to first field with error. Preserve all user data when validation errors occur.

sections.title: Cognitive Accessibility
sections.description: Present one question per page, show clear progress indication, use consistent terminology, include review pages for important submissions.

sections.title: Comprehensive Accessibility Testing
sections.description: Keyboard navigation, screen reader testing, error message association, proper labeling, color contrast verification.

content_guidelines.value: **Focus testing checklist.** Does focus land on unique heading after clicking Continue? Is focused item visible? Does screen reader immediately announce step/page name?
**Error messages.** Provide specific, actionable error messages in plain language. Example: 'Enter a valid 9-digit Social Security number' rather than 'Invalid input'.
**Cognitive design.** Present one question per page, show clear progress, use consistent terminology, provide format examples.

accessibility.value: **WCAG 2.4.3 Focus Order.** Focus moves in a logical sequence that preserves meaning and operability.
**WCAG 2.4.7 Focus Visible.** Keyboard focus indicator must be visible.
**WCAG 3.3.2 Labels/Instructions.** Labels or instructions are provided when content requires user input.
**WCAG 3.3.3 Error Suggestion.** Correction suggestions provided for detected errors.
**WCAG 4.1.3 Status Messages.** Form validation changes must be programmatically determinable.
**Required testing areas.** Keyboard navigation, screen reader testing (NVDA, JAWS, VoiceOver), error message association, proper labeling, color contrast.
**Multi-step specific testing.** Screen reader announcements for step changes, progress bar updates, focus movement after error correction, session persistence.
**Foundational testing before launch.** Color and contrast evaluation, automated testing with aXe DevTools, content zoom and reflow, keyboard navigation.
**Support available.** The Accessibility Digital Experience (ADE) team provides early guidance during planning phases.

metadata.title: Welcome
metadata.description: Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin.

blogPosts.content:
[Docusaurus blogging features](https://docusaurus.io/docs/blog) are powered by the [blog plugin](https://docusaurus.io/docs/api/plugins/@docusaurus/plugin-content-blog).

Here are a few tips you might find useful.

<!-- truncate -->

Simply add Markdown files (or folders) to the `blog` directory.

Regular blog authors can be added to `authors.yml`.

The blog post date can be extracted from filenames, such as:

- `2019-05-30-welcome.md`
- `2019-05-30-welcome/index.md`

A blog post folder can be convenient to co-locate blog post images:

![Docusaurus Plushie](./docusaurus-plushie-banner.jpeg)

The blog supports tags as well!

**And if you don't want a blog**: just delete this directory, and use `blog: false` in your Docusaurus config.
